Tribute page to Dr. Martin Luther King Jr

Who was Dr. Martin Luther King Jr?

Martin Luther King Jr. was born in Atlanta, Georgia, on January 15, 1929, to Martin Luther King, a Baptist minister and Irene King. His parents were college-educated, and King’s father was the pastor of the prestigious Ebenezer Baptist Church in Atlanta.

Although he had a comfortable upbringing, this did not exclude him from experiencing the racial prejudices common in the South at that time. Dr. King spent his first extended stay away from home outsite the south in 1944. There his experience of how peacefully the race relations were deepened his growing hatred of racial segregation

In 1944, at age 15, King entered Morehouse College in Atlanta. He favored studies in medicine and law but decided to enter the ministry in his senior year. he graduated from Morehouse in 1948.

He spent the next three years at Crozer Theological Seminary in Chester, Pennsylvania and earned a bachelor of divinity degree in 1951. King was elected president of Crozer’s student body, which was comprised of majority of white students. A professor recommended King stating:

“The fact that with our student body largely Southern in constitution a colored man should be elected to and be popular in such a position is in itself no mean recommendation.”

From Crozer, King went on to Boston University, where he received a doctorate (1955) for a dissertation titled “A Comparison of the Conceptions of God in the Thinking of Paul Tillich and Henry Nelson Wieman.”

The life of Martin Luther King, Jr.

Brief timeline of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr's life:

  • 1929: Born in Atlanta, Georgia
  • 1944:Began his freshman year at Morehouse College in Atlanta.
  • 1946:Wrote letter to The Atlanta Constitution editor stating that black people "are entitled to the basic rights and opportunities of American citizens." which was published
  • 1948:Ordained and appointed assistant pastor at Ebenezer Baptist Church in Atlanta.
  • 1948:Earned his Bachelor of Arts degree in sociology from Morehouse College.
  • 1948:Began studies at Crozer Theological Seminary in Chester, Pennsylvania.
  • 1951:Graduated from Crozer Theological Seminary and delivered the valedictory speech
  • 1948:Began studies at studies in systematic theology at Boston University.
  • 1953:Married Coretta Scott
  • 1954:Began his pastorate at Dexter Avenue Baptist Church in Montgomery, Alabama.
  • 1955:Earned his doctorate in systematic theology from Boston University.
  • 1955:Earned his doctorate in systematic theology from Boston University.
  • 1955:Became the president of the Montgomery Improvement Association (MIA) formed after the arrest of Rosa Parks for refusing to give up her seat on the bus.
  • 1956:Led the Montgomery Bus Boycott for 385 days, which succeded with the US Supreme Court ruling that segregation on public buses was unconstitutional.
  • 1957:Became the president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference (SCLC).
  • 1957:Delivered his first national address advocating voting rights for African Americans in the United States, named “Give Us the Ballot,” at the Prayer Pilgrimage for Freedom at the Lincoln Memorial in Washington.
  • 1958:Met with President Dwight Eisenhower in Washington.
  • 1960:Moved from Montgomery to Atlanta to focus on the civil rights struggle.
  • 1960:Arrested at a sit-in demonstration at an Atlanta department store.
  • 1961:Arrested alongside hundreds of others in a desegregation campaign in Albany, Ga.
  • 1963:Led the Birmingham campaign which gained nationwide attention when the Birmingham Police Department used high-pressure water jets and police attack dogs on the children who joined the campaign. The movement ended with the municipal government changing the city’s discriminatory laws.
  • 1963:Wrote his famous Letter from a Birmingham Jail, a defense of nonviolent resistance to racism after getting arrested for ignoring an Alabama state court injunction against demonstrations.
  • 1963:King was one of the leaders who organized the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom, one of the largest political rallies for human rights in US history with over 250,000 participants where he delivered his “I Have a Dream” speech at the Lincoln Memorial.
  • 1964:Time magazine named King “Man of the Year” for 1963.
  • 1964:Became the youngest recipient of the Nobel Peace Prize for leading non-violent resistance to racial prejudice in the U.S.
  • 1965:After voting rights marchers are attacked and beaten by police in Selma, Alabama, King peacefully leads civil rights marchers from Selma to Montgomery.
  • 1965:Gave his first speech against the Vietnam War.
  • 1965:Organized and led marches advocating for the voting right of blacks, desegregation, labor rights and other civil rights.
  • 1965:The Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the 1965 Voting Rights Act were passed and majority of these rights were enacted into law due to his efforts.
  • 1966:Moved with his wife to a Chicago slum apartment in a bid to demand better housing and education in northern U.S. cities.
  • 1967:Gave speech at a New York City church demanding that the U.S. make greater effort to end Vietnam War.
  • 1968:Led 6,000 protesters in support of striking sanitation workers in Memphis.
  • 1968:Delivered “I’ve Been to the Mountaintop, his final speech.
  • 1968:Was assasinated while standing on the balcony of the Lorraine Motel, in Memphis, Tennessee, on April 4, 1968.

Throughout the world, Dr Martin Luther King Jnr is recognized as the symbolic leader of African Americans. From 1957 till his assassination, he traveled over six million miles and spoke over twenty-five hundred times. He also led multiple protests, wrote five books and several articles.

Dr Martin Luther King's achievements are testimony to the belief that one man's determination, contributions and advocacy can be instrumental to achieving lasting change and progress.
